  • Method Details

    • setNoPerspective

      public final void setNoPerspective()
      Notifies the varying handler that this shader will never emit geometry in perspective and therefore does not require perspective-correct interpolation. When supported, this allows varyings to use the "noperspective" keyword, which means the GPU can use cheaper math for interpolation.

    • addVarying

      public final void addVarying(String name, Varying varying)
      Convenience for addVarying(String, Varying, int) that uses smooth or noperspective interpolation.

    • addVarying

      public final void addVarying(String name, Varying varying, int interpolation)
      addVarying allows fine-grained control for setting up varyings between stages. Calling this function will make sure all necessary decls are setup for the client. The client however is responsible for setting up all shader code (e.g "vOut = vIn;") If you just need to take an attribute and pass it through to an output value in a fragment shader, use addPassThroughAttribute.

    • addPassThroughAttribute

      public final void addPassThroughAttribute(GeometryProcessor.Attribute attr, String output)
      Convenience for addPassThroughAttribute(GeometryProcessor.Attribute, String, int) that uses smooth or noperspective interpolation.

    • addPassThroughAttribute

      public final void addPassThroughAttribute(GeometryProcessor.Attribute attr, String output, int interpolation)
      The GP can use these calls to pass a vertex shader variable directly to 'output' in the fragment shader. Though this adds code to vertex and fragment stages, 'output' is expected to be defined in the fragment shader before the call is made.

    • finish

      public final void finish()

    • onFinish

      protected void onFinish()
